title: Matrix
content:
Are there any typefaces that have 45 degree diagonal serifs like Zuzana Licko’s [Matrix](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430120106/http:/www.emigre.com/EFfeature.php?di=105)? I’d like to see the effect of this kind of serif on legibility before I start realising an idea which I want to excecute.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430120106im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/MAT1_6592.gif)

So far, the one’s I know of are:

Matrix  
Mitim

 [‹ Font Rage](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430120106/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34911 "Go to previous forum topic") [Evolution of the Latin script ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430120106/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34967 "Go to next forum topic")
author: D. Wiewauters

comments.content:
In case it helps your research, this type of serif is called “Latin”  
(although often this includes serifs that don’t have totally sharp  
ends, like Azuza\*). BTW, a good example is Saracen: [http://www.typography.com/catalog/saracen/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430120106/http:/www.typography.com/catalog/saracen/index.html "http://www.typography.com/catalog/saracen/index.html")

\* See the description here:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/parkinson/azuza/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430120106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/parkinson/azuza/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/parkinson/azuza/")

Latin serif fonts were big in France in  
the second half of the 19th century.
